src_text: Mutindu NSA, yandi salaka na Carter na mambu me tadila kumonisa insi na mambu ya ntoto ya muvimba, mutindu Kuwakana ya Camp David, na 1978; sambu na kuvutula nsalasaki ya kintuadi kati na Amerika -Chine na 1970; Kimpwanza ya bana ya Iran, yina nataka mpasi ya Iran na 1979; na luyalu ya Afganistan na kukota ya bantu ya Sovietique na 1979.
ref_text: As NSA, he assisted Carter in diplomatically handling world affairs, such as the Camp David Accords, 1978; normalizing US–China relations thought the late 1970s; the Iranian Revolution, which led to the Iran hostage crisis, 1979; and the Soviet invasion in Afghanistan, 1979.
hyp_text: Meanwhile, the NSA had already infiltrated the Carter administration and had been monitoring the communications of the Soviet Union's KGB, as well as the Chinese and Iranian governments, since the 1970s; it had also been monitoring the situation in Afghanistan, where the Soviet Union had invaded in 1979, and had been secretly providing aid to the anti-Soviet mujahideen.

src_text: Bangindu mingi ya ke tadila Déterministe Technologique ke vandaka ti mabanza zole: kuyela ya technologie yo mosi ke landaka nzila yina ke wakana ve ti bupusi ya kinkulu to ya politiki, mpe nde technologie ke vandaka na "boupusi" na luzingu ya bantu kele ya kuwakana kansi ve mambu ya luzingu.
ref_text: Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general ideas: that the development of technology itself follows a path largely beyond cultural or political influence, and that technology in turn has "effects" on societies that are inherent, rather than socially conditioned.
hyp_text: Many technological determinists believe that technology has always been driven by a single goal: to improve the human condition, and that technology has always been driven by a desire to overcome the limitations of the human body and the constraints of politics, and that technology has always been driven by a desire to 'surpass' human limitations and achieve a higher level of civilization.

hyp_text: Many people of subcultures are known for their unique and creative ways of expressing themselves, often blending different styles and genres, which can lead to the creation of something new and innovative, and ultimately, to the development of a distinct identity and a sense of belonging.
